## _Condé Nast Traveler_ Assistant Web Editor Molly Fergus shares her favorite Chicago meals and restaurants

## 
1. **[Big Star](http://bigstarchicago.com/# )** When the sun finally comes out in Chicago, I can think of few things I’d rather be doing than sipping a (very potent) margarita on Big Star’s patio. Most people go for the tacos, but I could down an entire order of queso fundido by myself. The gooey, melted blend of Chihuahua cheese, crumbled chorizo, and spicy rajas poblano—browned on top and spooned into fresh corn tortillas, because chips would crack under the weight of this stuff—is addicting. (1531 N. Damen; 773-235-4039)



## 
1.           **[Hot Doug’s](http://www.hotdougs.com/ )** Doug Sohn’s sausage emporium is so popular that some die-hard fans [get tattoos of the restaurant’s logo](http://leisureblogs.chicagotribune.com/thestew/2010/11/get-a-hot-dougs-tattoo-eat-hot-dougs-for-free-for-life-.html) in exchange for a lifetime’s supply of free food. I prefer to just pay for the delicious hot dogs. The Chicago-style version is a must, but you’ll also want to sample one of the fancy-pants varieties (Sohn has a menu of classics, but his rotating specials include things like a foie gras and sauternes duck sausage topped with truffle aioli, foie gras mousse, and fleur de sel). I suggest bringing a friend, splitting two, and digging into an order of fresh-cut fries—on Saturday and Sunday, the spuds are sizzled in duck fat. Warning: There is almost always a line out the door and around the corner, even if you have a hot dog tattoo. (3324 N. California; 773-279-9550) 







## 
1.           **[Thin Crust Pizza](http://www.mariespizzachicago.com/Maries_Pizza_%26_Liquors/Welcome.html )** I love deep-dish pizza, but those doughy, three-inch-tall pies from Lou Malnati’s are not an everyday thing. Growing up, my family ordered in a thin-crust pie every Friday night from a handful of nearby mom-and-pop pizzerias. You'll see these pizzerias all over the city, but Marie's on the Northwest side is a classic choice. The Albany Park pizza joint/liquor store hybrid has been serving crispy pies since 1940, and the place has hardly changed since. A regional quirk: Thin crust pizzas are cut into small, checkerboard squares instead of floppy slices. The technique leaves plenty of crust-free middle pieces and a few crunchy, bite-sized triangles on the edges (my favorites). (4127 W. Lawrence Ave.; 773-725-1812)



## 
1. ** Paradise Pup **When I'm waiting in one of Shake Shack's maddeningly long lines in New York, my mind often drifts to this divey hamburger stand in my hometown, just outside of Chicago (and, if you're ambitious, close enough to O'Hare for a meal during a long layover). It's the kind of small family place that can close for the afternoon just by posting a note on the door, but the line at lunch rivals anything I've seen at Madison Square Park. Most everyone is there for the cheeseburger. It's a beef patty (medium) piled with lettuce, tomato, and the two show-stoppers—grilled onions and a half-inch-thick slathering of Merkt's cheddar cheese, the soft and creamy kind you usually spread on crackers with a butter knife. You can order fries smothered in the stuff, too, but the DIY tactic—scraping some off the sides of the burger—works just as well.          (1724 S. River Rd.; 847-699-8590) 







## 
1. **          [Hopleaf](http://hopleaf.com/ )** There’s nothing wrong, really, about coming to this Andersonville tavern just for the beer: More than 40 drafts and another 250 bottled varieties await. But you should eat, and you should eat the mussels. I order them Belgian-style, bathed in a Wittekerke white ale sauce and served with a grease-speckled paper cone of fries. The frites sop up the mussel juice beautifully, but the aioli sauce is its own treat—I switch off between the two while deciding which beer to order next. (5148 N. Clark St.; 773-334-9851)
